conclusion: The particle starts from rest (initial velocity v₀ = 0). The first graph shows acceleration (a) vs time (t), and the second graph shows velocity (v) vs time (t). We need to find when the particle is farthest from the starting point.

From the acceleration-time graph: (1) From t = 0 to t = t₀/2, a = a₀. (2) From t = t₀/2 to t = t₀, a decreases linearly from a₀ to 0. (3) From t = t₀ to t = 3t₀/2, a decreases linearly from 0 to -a₀. (4) From t = 3t₀/2 to t = 2t₀, a increases linearly from -a₀ to 0.

From the velocity-time graph: (1) The velocity starts at 0 (particle starts from rest). (2) The velocity increases to a maximum value of a₀t₀/2 around t = t₀. (3) The velocity decreases back to 0 at t = 2t₀.

premise: The displacement of the particle equals the area under the velocity-time curve.
conclusion: To find when the particle is farthest from the starting point, I need to find when the displacement is at its maximum.

premise: The velocity-time graph shows that velocity is always positive from t = 0 to t = 2t₀ (the curve stays above the t-axis).
conclusion: The displacement continually increases during this time.

premise: The velocity becomes zero again at t = 2t₀.
conclusion: The particle will be farthest from the starting point at t = 2t₀.

premise: From t = 0 to t = 2t₀, the particle is moving in the positive direction (v > 0). At t = 2t₀, the particle stops (v = 0).
conclusion: After t = 2t₀, if the motion were to continue, the particle would start moving back.

premise: The particle stops at t = 2t₀ after moving in the positive direction.
conclusion: At t = 2t₀, the particle is farthest from the starting point.
